Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Vegetation Feedback and Regional Climate Predictions in West Africa
Award.AbstractNarration:
The CO2-induced future climate changes and the resulting ecological consequence pose tremendous socioeconomic challenges. Development of long-term strategies for adaptation and mitigation relies on accurate prediction of such changes at regional scale. The goal of this project is to improve our capability and confidence in predicting future climate and vegetation changes in West Africa. In this project the National Center for Atmospheric Research Community Land Model version 4 including the dynamic global vegetation model (CLM4-DGVM) will be coupled synchronously to the International Center of Theoretical Physics Regional Climate Model version 4 (RegCM4); the resulting fully coupled model and its component models will be used to investigate the vegetation-climate interactions in West Africa in the context of regional climate predictions. Uncertainties related to lateral boundary conditions will be addressed by the use of output from multiple global climate models. A large set of experiments will be conducted to address several specific questions, including (1) Why do the regional climate model and its driving global model predict different future precipitation trends? How do different aspects of the lateral boundary conditions influence the precipitation trend simulated in the regional climate model? (2) How does dynamic vegetation feedback influence the predicted future trend of precipitation, including the precipitation amount, intensity, and seasonality? (3) How do future climate changes modify the competition between different vegetation types? This project will advance our understanding on vegetation-climate interactions and the resulting impact on regional climate prediction, and characterize uncertainties in regional climate predictions. While some of the results (e.g., the high sensitivity of regional climate to vegetation feedback) might be region-dependent, the scientific questions to be addressed and the process-based understanding derived from this project are applicable to other regions and other models.

Broader impact: (1) Results from this project will be disseminated to local analysts and policy makers in African countries through the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) African country offices, and to researchers at the IFPRI?s Harvest Choice program, to inform food policy making and long-term agricultural research and development investment; (2) Involving middle school girls and middle- and high-school teachers, this project will promote teaching and learning in a broad context and enhance participation of under-represented groups in geosciences; (3) Results from this project will support major multi-model inter-comparison efforts including the West African Monsoon Modeling and Evaluation (WAMME) project and the Coordinated Regional Climate Downscaling Experiment (CORDEX-Africa) project.

This project is a collaborative effort between the University of Connecticut and Loyola Marymount University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using West Africa as an example, the overarching goal of this project is to improve our capability and confidence in predicting future climate and vegetation changes in

West Africa. Specific objectives of this project are:

(1) To quantify and understand the impact of dynamic vegetation feedback on predicted future changes of precipitation in West Africa?

(2) To understand the difference in predicted future precipitation trend between RCM and the driving GCMs?

(3) To understand mechanisms underlying the predicted changes of vegetation distribution in West Africa.

To meet these objectives, we developed a fully coupled regional climate-dynamic vegetation model by coupling the NCAR CLM4.5-CNDV model to the ICTP RegCM4.3.4 model, and using this newly developed model to conduct a future projection study using a multi-model ensemble modeling approach.

 

Major findings from this project include:

1) Including vegetation-climate interactions in a model imposes a much higher criterion for model performance, as biases in the climate model and vegetation model feed upon each other, enhancing model biases and causing climate drift. This highlights the need for substantial model development effort to address model biases in both climate and vegetation models in order to take full advantage of the added capacities in the coupled models.

2) Although the GCMs project contradicting future rainfall trends over West Africa, the GCMs-driven RCM produced future trends that are generally consistent among each other. The multi-model ensemble projects significant decreases of rainfall over a major portion of West Africa and significant increases over eastern Sahel and East Africa.

3) LAI and NPP are projected to significant increases in most of Tropical Africa despite decrease of precipitation in some areas. This increase is due primarily to the physiological effects of CO2 concentration increase that causes densification of vegetation in some areas and tree expansion over grasslands in others.

4) Dynamic vegetation feedback leads to a wet signal for future climate projections in Tropical Africa, and the signal is especially significant in areas of tree expansion.

5) In RCM modeling, multi-model ensemble addressing uncertainty related to the driving GCMs can be accomplished using the newly proposed Ensemble Reconstructed Forcing approach, which attains the same level of accuracy with only a fraction of the computational cost compared with the conventional approach.

6) The RCM-projected future rainfall trend is dominated by the RCM response to the temperature elements of future boundary condition changes from GCMs. This may be a major cause for the higher level of consensus among RCM projections than GCM projections found in this project.

7) The current practice of exerting large-scale forcings at the RCM domain boundaries may fail to capture the true extent to which large scale forcings may influence the domain climate. This is especially the case in regions where oceanic impact is important (e.g., Amazon). Realistic RCM modeling requires a model domain that encompasses the most influential oceans.

 

In addition to improved scientific understanding, the project produced: (1) a regional climate system model that is currently being used by several other groups in the research community; (2) a multi-model ensemble modeling approach (the Ensemble Reconstructed Forcing approach) that is likely to be adopted by major international projects on regional climate projections; and (3) a new paradigm of regional climate modeling that emphasizes the impact of influential oceanic, which can fundamentally change the way how regional modeling is conducted.    

 

Research in this project merits the publication of 11 journal articles (7 published, 2 submitted, and 2 soon-to-be-submitted) and a large number of conference presentations including two invited talks, and contribute materials to class projects for graduate students and to presentations used in the PI’s outreach activities. The project has supported the M.S. thesis research of one female student,  supported (partially) the PhD dissertation research of one student, trained one female postdoctoral researcher, one female visiting scholar, and one female undergraduate researcher who was inspired by this project to pursue a PhD degree in the PI’s group.
